questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with itchy skin lesions on his face. for the past 3 days. On examination, there are erythematous lesions near the mouth with honey-yellow crusting, as shown in the image given below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image showing erythematous lesions with honey-colored crusts is suggestive of impetigo contagiosa (a.k.a non-bullous impetigo).

Impetigo is a type of bacterial skin infection, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes. It is self-limiting, has an incubation period of 4-10 days, and lasts for about two-three weeks.

Topical antibiotics are preferable to oral antibiotics for limited impetigo. Three topical antibiotics recommended for impetigo are mupirocin 2%, retapamulin 1% ointment, and fusidic acid.

Option B: The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus. 

The below image shows the lesions seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is classically associated with facial infections causing herpes labialis or cold sore.  Below image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base which is characteristic of herpes labialis.

Option D : Cellulitis is an acute subacute or chronic inflammation of loose connective tissue usually due to a bacterial infection. It presents as a diffuse swelling associated with pain and tenderness.The given image shows how the edges of the lesion in cellulitis are diffuse.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas- Infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. 

The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with all except _____
questions.solution:
Amnesia is characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome, not Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a specific aetiology of delirium which is caused by thiamine deficiency, commonly due to alcohol abuse.  

Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Acute, neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait (ataxia).
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy is a medical emergency, and thiamine should be initiated immediately, either intravenously or intramuscularly.  

Korsakoff syndrome:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by a pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with potential impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning.
  • Permanent in at least a partial form in about 50 percent of the people affected.    

Korsakoff Syndrome

Thiamine deficiency

  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Anton syndrome(visual anosognosia)

Occipital lobe damage (Usually due to stroke)

  • Cortical blindness
  • Confabulation

Kluver Bucy syndrome 

Bitemporal lesions

  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde Amnesia
  • Visual agnosia
  • Hyperphagia
  • Hyperorality
  • Hypersexuality

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. On KOH mount, spaghetti and meatballs appearance is noted. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The characteristic appearance of ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes' on KOH mount and microscopy (shown below) is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.

Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is another characteristic finding of tinea versicolor. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Option A: Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch, is a dermatophyte infection affecting the inguinal folds, which may extend to the vulva and perianal area. 

Option B:  Tinea capitis, also known as scalp ringworm, is a fungal infection affecting the scalp. 

Option C: Tinea corporis, is a fungal infection, which can occur anywhere in the body, with the classical ring shaped/annular rash. 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text:
Match the following skull radiology findings and the associated conditions.
1) Salt and pepper appearance A) Hurler's syndrome
2) J-shaped sella B) Paget's disease
3) Punched-out lesions C) Hyperparathyroidism
4) Cotton wool appearance D) Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  • Salt and pepper appearance - Hyperparathyroidism 
  • J-shaped sella - Hurler's syndrome
  • Punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma
  • Cotton wool appearance - Paget's disease

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor, generally affecting maxilla/ mandible

Image showing salt and pepper appearance of the skull:

\J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler's syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note:

J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Punched-out lesions - It is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

Cotton wool appearance - It is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

questions.text: All of the following forms the right cardiac border on the chest X-ray PA view except:
questions.solution:
On a chest x-ray PA view, the right ventricle does not form the right cardiac border.

Right cardiac border formed by:

  • SVC
  • Right atrium
  • IVC

Left cardiac border formed by:

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knob/ knuckle (Aortic Arch)
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

The right ventricle is the most anteriorly placed cardiac chamber. It forms the inferior border on the chest X-ray PA view.

Given below is a list of normal silhouettes on chest radiographs as seen on the PA view. The loss of these silhouettes are indicative of the site of pathology:

Obliterated silhouette Site of pathology
Right para-tracheal stripe Right upper lobe
Right heart border Right middle lobe or
medial right lower lobe
Right hemidiaphragm Right lower lobe
Aortic knuckle Left upper lobe
(posterior segment)
Left heart border Lingula segments of 
left upper lobe
Left hemidiaphragm 
or descending aorta		 Left lower lobe

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police. He came to the police station accusing his daughter of wanting to kill him. The police on investigating the family and the neighbors understood that it was a false accusation. His physical examination is not remarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient thinks that his daughter wants to kill him which is not true. Since the patient appears normal apart from the delusion, the clinical scenario is likely to be of a delusional disorder, more specifically delusion of persecution. 

Delusion is a false belief, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

Other options:

Option B: Illusion is an incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

Option C: Hallucination: Perception in the absence of any stimulus. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake.

Option D: Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Exclamation mark hair pattern is seen in:
questions.solution:
Exclamation mark hair pattern is seen in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

Other options:

Option B: Trichotillomania (trichotillosis) is considered an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) spectrum disorder, marked by gratification from pulling one's own hair. It could be associated with underlying anxieties or depression. The vertex region of the scalp is most commonly involved. Scalp histology will show perifollicular hemorrhages and intrafollicular pigment casts. 

Option C: Telogen effluvium leads to diffuse hair loss that affects all hair equally, not just pigmented hair. So, overall hair color will not be affected.

Option D: Androgenic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fibre production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types, male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female reported symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, and a feeling of impending doom. She recalls having experienced 5-6 similar episodes in the past 6 months, each episode lasting for about 20-30 minutes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic disorder.  Panic disorder refers to an acute intense attack of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Such attacks may not only occur in response to a fearful situation, or phobic objects, or in response to obsession or separation as in other anxiety disorders.

Panic disorder is characterized by the presence of an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes. They may occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable stimulus. During the episode, the person may experience symptoms like palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, shortness of breath, nausea, dizziness, chest pain or discomfort or fear of dying. The patient also might feel like losing control, having a heart attack, or going crazy.

Some habits predispose a patient to panic attacks. These include the use of caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, or other substances, and unusual patterns of sleeping or eating. 

 

For rapid control of symptoms, alprazolam is the drug of choice. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as paroxetine are started concurrently and alprazolam is slowly tapered. Fluoxetine is used for panic attacks with co-morbid depression.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Basic life support involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat.

Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Jaw thrust- Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

 

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. Fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are incorrectly matched with their imaging modality of choice?

choices.text: Hirschsprung’s disease- Plain x-ray abdomen with air contrast
Neonatal hepatitis- Nuclear medicine; hepatobiliary scintigraphy

questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrografin enema. 

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel. 

 

Other options:

Transfontanel cranial ultrasonography or a neurosonogram reliably delineates ventricular size and anatomy in neonates. It is an excellent primary imaging technique for the evaluation of the many clinical problems related to ventricular dilatation. 

  1. Ventriculomegaly
  2. Differentiating nonobstructive ventricular dilatation from obstructive enlargement (hydrocephalus)
  3. Cause of hydrocephalus
  4. Temporary management of patients with hydrocephalus
  5. Aiding in the management of patients with permanent ventricular shunts

Ultrasound in pyloric stenosis will show a dilated, fluid-filled stomach and proximal duodenum with obstruction. A coexisting volvulus can show as a whirlpool sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy is a radionuclide imaging that shows metabolic activity in different cell types based on the substance taken up by the various cells.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in her knee. Histopathology of the lesion showed a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells seen scattered amidst round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The stroma appeared well vascularized, with bands of fibrous tissue with areas of hemorrhage and collections of foamy macrophages interspersed in between. Which of the following x-rays belongs to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and characteristic histopathology findings are suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT), or osteoclastoma. The x-ray findings of GCT are seen in Image 2, which shows an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular lesion, with a soap-bubble appearance.

A GCT is typically seen on x-ray as an eccentric, lobulated, lytic lesion with non-sclerotic borders, giving a soap-bubble appearance. GCTs usually have little or no matrix calcification, new bone formation, or periosteal reaction. Tumors that extend into the soft tissues are seen as soft-tissue masses, which may be covered by a thin layer of sclerosis. They are usually located in the epiphysis of the long bone, but may also extend to the metaphysis. If malignant, the tumor appears as a lytic lesion with a sclerosing destructive tumor adjacent to it.

CT imaging estimates cortical bone involvement, and MRI shows an isointense or hypointense lesion on T1-weighted images.

GCTs are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the bone and are characterized by a proliferation of mononuclear cells, with scattered macrophages. They are most commonly seen at 20–45 years of age. GCTs may occasionally be associated with Paget’s disease of bone and focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

They are seen in the epiphysis of long bones, more commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. Patients present with pain and a mass. 

Histologically, GCTs consist of a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells, with scattered, round, or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized, with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. Interposed areas of hemorrhage, hemosiderin, and foamy macrophages are seen.

The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

Other options:

Image 1: It shows Brodie's abscess, which is a small cavity in the bone with little or no periosteal reaction, seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

Image 3: It shows multiple osteochondromas around the knee joint. An osteochondroma is a common benign, cartilaginous neoplasm, seen more often in males during adolescent years. Pedunculated osteochondromas typically point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis.

Image 4: It shows osteosarcoma with a sunburst appearance. They appear as ill-defined, bone-forming lesions causing cortical destruction, periosteal reaction, and expansion into the soft tissues. Codman’s triangle may be visualized where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation.

 

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age

Enchondroma

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

(Exostosis)

Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade

questions.text:
Which of the following can be classified as ionizing radiation?
  1. Alpha rays
  2. Beta rays
  3. Gamma rays
  4. X-rays
  5. MRI
questions.solution:
Among the given options, alpha rays, beta rays, gamma rays, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. MRI is an example of non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. 

Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation with enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from the orbit of an atom, causing the atom to be charged or ionized. They can be either directly ionizing or indirectly ionizing. Alpha rays and beta rays are directly ionizing radiation because they carry a charge and can directly interact with atomic electrons. Alpha and beta rays are also particulate radiation (composed of particles). 

Gamma rays and x-rays are electromagnetic rays. They are indirectly ionizing radiation as they are electrically neutral and do not interact directly with electrons. 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves. It uses non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. MRI is based on the ability of nuclei of certain atoms to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a widespread rash. It started on the chest and spread out over his body. On examination, there are multiple purpuric macules affecting the face and torso. Nikolsky's sign is positive. There is also the involvement of his mouth and eyes. The body surface area affected is 45%. He was recently started on allopurinol for gout. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). 

Stevens Johnson syndrome(SJS)/TEN is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

Eyes, oral mucosa, and genitals are frequently involved. 

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN  Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with or without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.  

The following image shows Nikolsky's sign, where the application of gentle lateral pressure causes sliding of the epidermis. 

The following image shows the involvement of the oral mucosa and large areas of loss of skin. 

Other options: 

Option C - Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease that mainly affects older people. It is characterized by pruritus with widespread tense blisters. It doesn't occur after consumption of allopurinol. There is no mucosal involvement. The following image shows bullous pemphigoid with unruptured, multiple-tense blisters. 

Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters. 

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

Earlier, erythema multiforme (EM), Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN or Lyell syndrome) were considered to form a spectrum from mild to fulminatingly severe cases. Now, this has been revised to separate Erythema multiforme as part of a different spectrum.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.


Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, in which SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
% Body Surface-area <10% <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position indicated?

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.solution:
The position illustrated in the picture is known as the recovery position, and it is used in the management of patients who are unconscious but with pulse present and breathing present.

The recovery position can help prevent complications such as aspiration and airway obstruction in unconscious individuals. Additionally, it is crucial to monitor the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation continuously while they are in the recovery position and seek immediate medical assistance. An unresponsive patient who is breathing spontaneously in the supine position is at risk of airway obstruction from their tongue, mucus, vomit, etc. A modified lateral position is used and the following 6 principles are considered while choosing which variation of recovery position to use,

  1. The victim should be in as near a true lateral position as possible, with the head dependent to allow free drainage of fluid.

  2. The position should be stable.

  3. Avoid any pressure on the chest that impairs breathing.

  4. It should be possible to turn the victim on his or her side and to return to the back easily and safely, with concern for a possible cervical spine injury.

  5. Good observation of and access to the airway should be possible.

  6. The position itself should not cause injury to the victim.

Other options

Option A: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent - In this situation, the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), not the recovery position. CPR involves chest compressions and rescue breaths to support circulation and respiration.

Option B: Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent - In this case, the patient is experiencing respiratory arrest. Rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to support the patient's breathing. The recovery position is not indicated in this scenario.

Option D: Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present - This option is not physiologically plausible, as the absence of a pulse implies a lack of circulation, and breathing cannot be present without circulation.

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: A 26-year-old term primigravida is taken to the operation theatre for an emergency cesarean section due to sudden fetal distress. The anaesthetist wants to prevent chances of pulmonary aspiration and decides to intubate using rapid sequence intubation. Which of the following steps is not performed in this technique?
questions.solution:
Bag and mask ventilation is avoided in rapid sequence intubation because it leads to stomach inflation and increases the risk of aspiration.

Indications of Rapid sequence intubation:

RSI is done when the patient is at increased risk of pulmonary aspiration as in:

  • pregnancy
  • full stomach
  • intestinal obstruction
  • hiatus hernia
  • encephalopathy
  • morbid obesity
  • diabetic gastroparesis.

questions.text: Which of the following airway devices helps in maintaining FiO2 of 0.25 to 0.60 irrespective of the patient's breathing effort?
questions.solution:
Venturi mask helps in maintaining FiO2 of 0.25 to 0.60 irrespective of patient's breathing effort.

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low-flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high-flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance oxygen delivery system and the highest oxygen concentration (FiO2) delivered is 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min. It is useful with patients who require greater FiO2 such as COPD patients, where it is important to provide controlled oxygenation. It is available in different colors, with the green valve venturi mask providing 60% FiO2. 

Color of Venturi valve FiO2 (%) Flow rate 
(L/min)
Blue 24  2
White 28  4
Orange 31  6
Yellow 35  8
Red 40  10
Green 60  15
Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Other options:

Option A: The nasal cannula is a low-flow variable performance oxygen delivery system that can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40% at flow rates greater than 10 L/ min for short periods. It is usually limited to a flow of 5-6 L/min to reduce the discomfort resulting from inadequate humidification and high flow into the nasal cavity. It may also cause drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

Option B: Hudson mask also known as a simple face mask is a Low-flow, variable-performance device. It provides an oxygen flow rate of up to 5-10 L/min and provides a variable FiO2. The body of the mask functions as a reservoir for both oxygen and expired carbon dioxide. It is used in patients who require oxygen therapy for shorter periods of time.

Option D: The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow variable device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air. This type of mask is used in patients with significant hypoxia, with relatively normal ventilation, such as victims of trauma or carbon monoxide exposure.

questions.text:
Arrange the following anesthetic agents on the basis of their potency.

Nitrous oxide, Halothane, Isoflurane, Methoxyflurane
questions.solution:
The potency of the inhaled anesthetics given above can be arranged as methoxyflurane> halothane> isoflurane> nitrous oxide. It is due to the change in the agents' minimum alveolar concentration (MAC).

The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic is the lowest concentration required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. It is a measure of the potency of inhalational anesthetics. So, the lower the MAC value, the lower the concentration of anesthetic drug required, implying the drug is more potent.

MAC values (expressed as a '%' of 1 atmosphere) of some anesthetic agents:

  • Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104 is the least potent inhaled anesthetic
  • Methoxyflurane – MAC- 0.2 (most potent)
  • Desflurane: 6.0 
  • Sevoflurane– 2.05
  • Isoflurane – 1.28
  • Halothane – 0.75

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent     

 Nitrous oxide>Desflurane 

Most epileptogenic  

 Enflurane

Most nephrotoxic  

 Methoxyflurane 

Most hepatotoxic 

 Halothane

questions.text: Identify the type of psoriasis in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The picture shows scattered drop-like papules and plaques suggestive of guttate psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is a distinct variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults. 

On examination, guttate psoriasis manifests as numerous, small scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as “drop-like” and typically manifest as round or slightly oval 2 to 10 mm papules. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs as shown below. 

 

The image below shows a typical lesion of psoriasis characterised by erythematous plaque covered with silvery scales, particularly over the extensor surfaces.

Other options:

Option B: Erythrodermic psoriasis is an uncommon type where almost the entire body is affected, and the patient is systemically ill. 

Option C: Pustular psoriasis is associated with the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.

Option D: Flexural/ inverse psoriasis has plaques affecting intertriginous folds, and scaling may be less prominent. It is shown in the image given below

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with acute onset of neck stiffness. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he has been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Treatment: anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

  • Akathisia: Extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs within 10 days of starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, encephalopathy, muscle rigidity, dystonia, diaphoresis, tachycardia and labile blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine.
  • Tardive dyskinesia: It is characterized by involuntary, choreoathetoid movements in patients treated with antipsychotic medications. This disorder would be unlikely to occur within a few days of the initiation of drug therapy.

questions.text: Psychogenic erectile dysfunction can be differentiated from organic erectile dysfunction by ______.

choices.text: Decreased vibratory perception in the penis
Absence of erection with any partner

questions.solution:
The presence of nocturnal penile tumescence almost rules out organic causes of erectile dysfunction.

Organic causes are considered negligible in the following:

  • Spontaneous erections at times when he does not plan to have intercourse.
  • Having morning erections or nocturnal penile tumescence (erection during REM sleep).
  • Only sporadic erectile dysfunction.
  • Having good erections with masturbation.
  • Having good erection with partners other than his usual one.

Organic (non-psychogenic) causes of erectile dysfunction:

  • Vasculogenic
  • Endocrinologic
  • Neurogenic
  • Iatrogenic

In the case of organic causes, there is a pathological causing erectile dysfunction because of which a person does not have even morning erections. In the case of psychogenic, there is no disease/pathological process interfering with erections. Hence a patient with psychogenic ED has morning erections.
